item.title: Portland protests: Trump and Biden clash over street violence
item.description: A man was shot dead in the city on Saturday, which has seen weeks of demonstrations.

item.title: Coronavirus: Push back GCSE and A-level exams, says Labour
item.description: Exams due in May should be pushed back as late as July to allow for more catch-up teaching, the party says.

item.title: Price of plastic carrier bags to double to 10p next year
item.description: The fee for single-use bags will rise to 10p and be extended to all shops from April 2021.

item.title: Coronavirus: Cases on Tui flight from Zante to Cardiff
item.description: All passengers on the flight to Cardiff from Zante have been told to self-isolate.

item.title: Eat Out to Help Out discount comes to an end
item.description: The government's dining discount scheme ends on Monday, but there are calls for it to be extended.

item.title: Coronavirus: India surpasses US for highest single-day rise in Covid-19 cases
item.description: The 78,761 new cases reported on Sunday is the largest number for a day anywhere in the world.

item.title: Government paid influencers to promote Test and Trace
item.description: Taxpayer money was used to pay influencers to promote Test and Trace.

item.title: Norway bunker partygoers poisoned with carbon monoxide
item.description: More than 20 people were hospitalised after attending the party in the Norwegian capital Oslo.

item.title: South Wales Police: Banwen rave organisers fined Â£10,000
item.description: People from around the UK have descended on a Welsh village for the illegal rave.

item.title: Capita to close over a third of offices permanently
item.description: Outsourcing firm Capita is looking to close offices as the trend for flexible working accelerates.

item.title: Girl thrown into air by kite in Taiwan
item.description: The three-year-old escaped with minor injuries after being lifted into the air by a gust of wind.

item.title: Withington attack: Arrest after woman stabbed while walking with son
item.description: A teenager is held on suspicion of attempted murder following the "vicious" attack.

item.title: The Papers: Tax rises 'backlash', and schools' budget 'crisis'
item.description: Several papers lead with criticism over Rishi Sunak's reported plans to raise taxes in the next Budget.

item.title: 'We need Eat Out To Help Out to run in the autumn'
item.description: A group of restaurateurs wants the Eat Out To Help Out scheme to be brought back in the autumn.

item.title: Mauritius oil spill: 'We want to protect our island'
item.description: Young locals are helping to prevent environmental damage after an oil leak from a ship that ran aground.

item.title: Coronavirus: From fitness training to feeding people
item.description: Gym owner Mike Hind and his team have been delivering care packages to vulnerable people.

item.title: Chadwick Boseman: Black Panther director Ryan Coogler pays emotional tribute
item.description: "The ancestors spoke through him," says Ryan Coogler in a long and loving tribute to the star.

item.title: Coronavirus: How to fly during a global pandemic
item.description: Jumping on a plane looks and feels different to how it did at the start of 2020.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Music is just an instinct to me'
item.description: Hamish used lockdown to master the piano, which helps him cope with the grief from the death of his mum.

item.title: Woman arrested for naked video on India's Lakshman Jhula bridge
item.description: The woman faces charges under India's internet law over the incident on the Lakshman Jhula bridge.

item.title: Going for a Lake District walk with Max the Miracle Dog
item.description: Kerry Irving and his three dogs have become an internet sensation, so the BBC joined them for a walk.

item.title: Hilary Swank on Netflix's sci-fi Away and the ultimate work-life dilemma
item.description: Hilary Swank talks about her role for Netflix as the commander on the first manned mission to Mars.

item.title: The search engine boss who wants to help us all plant trees
item.description: Christian Kroll is the boss of Ecosia, which donates 80% of its profits to tree-planting projects.

item.title: Sheffield United: Who wrote club anthem Greasy Chip Butty?
item.description: John Denver's 1974 hit Annie's Song has been the tune of Sheffield United's anthem for decades. Why?

item.title: The diary of my daughter's murder: 'We were in hell on earth'
item.description: Bea Jones started writing a diary as she tried to come to terms with the brutal murder of her daughter Moira.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: The fake news about schools that's misleading parents
item.description: A video claiming that children could be placed in quarantine at school could disrupt the start of term.

item.title: Man Utd agree Â£40m fee for Ajax midfielder Van de Beek
item.description: Manchester United close in on the signing of Ajax midfielder Donny van de Beek as the two clubs agree a fee in the region of Â£40m.

item.title: England chase 196 to beat Pakistan in second Twenty20
item.description: England brilliantly chase 196 to beat Pakistan by five wickets in the second Twenty20 international at Emirates Old Trafford.

item.title: Jockey Club chief resigns as inquiry upholds allegations of bullying & racist comments
item.description: The chief executive of the Jockey Club resigns after an independent inquiry upheld allegations of bullying, racist comments and the circulation of offensive material.

item.title: England v Pakistan: Eoin Morgan highlights from T20 victory at Old Trafford
item.description: Watch the best of Eoin Morgan's masterful innings as the England captain makes 66 to help England chase 196 and beat Pakistan by five wickets

item.title: England's Bronze wins third Champions League as Lyon beat Wolfsburg
item.description: Dominant French club Lyon win the Women's Champions League for a fifth straight year, aided by England's Lucy Bronze.

item.title: 'A US Open like we've never seen before as Grand Slam tennis returns'
item.description: For the first time since the world was gripped by coronavirus, one of the four major tournaments is taking place when the US Open starts on Monday.

item.title: England v Pakistan: Tom Banton hits 'incredible' reverse paddle for six
item.description: England opener Tom Banton hits an "incredible" reverse paddle for six as England beat Pakistan in second T20 at Emirates Old Trafford.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: Travellers arriving from places like France and Spain must follow certain rules on entry to the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: Will the 'eat out to help out scheme' be extended?
item.description: Some restaurant chains say they will continue to offer a discount.

item.title: Coronavirus in the UK: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Europe lockdown: New coronavirus rules country by country
item.description: What are European countries doing to control new coronavirus outbreaks?

item.title: Coronavirus: Are teachers more at risk of coronavirus?
item.description: Children are at low risk from the disease, but concerns have been raised for teachers.

item.title: UK travel restrictions: Are Greece and Turkey on the quarantine list?
item.description: Key holiday spots are being regularly added to the travel quarantine list as infection rates rise.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does Covid-19 test-and-trace work?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to avoid catching the virus indoors
item.description: Good ventilation could be key to avoiding coronavirus this autumn as people spend more time indoors.

item.title: Flu: Why we still need to worry about it this winter
item.description: Drive-through vaccination clinics and extra staff are being considered for England's biggest flu vaccination programme.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: Many weddings were cancelled during lockdown, while some will have to change to meet the new rules.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: The guidance on who should wear face coverings varies around the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: What powers do the police have?
item.description: Coronavirus lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but who is responsible for enforcing them?

item.title: Coronavirus: What does my boss have to do to keep me safe?
item.description: The government wants more people to return to the workplace - but what precautions must employers take?

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key charts and maps explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world.

item.title: ICYMI: Aquarium art and crop portraits
item.description: Plus a newborn puma and pioneering women statues in our round-up of stories you may have missed this week.

item.title: Swanage RNLI lifeboat rescue recreated by 11-year-old animator
item.description: The animation about a Swanage lifeboat launch has been viewed more than 100,000 times.

item.title: 'SharkCam' films basking sharks off Scotland
item.description: The robot was deployed in UK waters for the first time in a project to observe basking sharks off Scotland.

item.title: Penarth 'dinosaur footprints' investigated by museum
item.description: The prospect of a "really, really exciting" find will be checked by the Natural History Museum, experts say.

item.title: Greta Thunberg: What she did during her year-long school break
item.description: The 17-year-old has gone back to education after a year of climate change activism.

item.title: West End 'eccentric's' bizarre collection sold at auction
item.description: Tony Parker's possessions included a full-scale model zebra and a fossilised walrus penis bone.
